I have added Secretary entering with rest, since Cardinal speaks to someone at tln ####, but have placed the Secretary's entrance among the rest of the party rather than at the end of the stage direction, as Foakes and McMullan have.

At this point Wolsey shifts from first person singular to first person plural. While this is a subtle shift, it occurs at a point that suggests that Wolsey has, in fact, been overreaching his authority.

note.lem: A noyse within crying roome for the Queene, vsher'd by the Duke of Norfolke. Enter the Queene, Norfolke and
note.level: The repetition of the reference to the Duke of Norfolk in the stage direction in F1 has resulted in several interpretations beginning with F4. I have chosen to emphasize the off-stage cry and include the first reference to Norfolk as part of that announcement.

In his note 7, Theobald notes that " ... We heard before, from Brandon, of one Nicholas Hopkins; and now his Name is chang'd into Henton; so that Brandon and the Surveyor seem to be in two Stories. There is, however, but one and the same Person meant, Hopkins; as I have restor'd in the Text: nor will it be any Difficulty to account for the other Name, when we come to consider that He was a Monk of the Convent, call'd Henton, near Bristol. So both Hall and Holingshed acquaint us. And he might, according to the Custom of those Times, be call'd as wel Nicholas of Henton, from the Place; as Hopkins, from his Family. I formerly set the Text right; and Mr. Pope has since acceded to my Alteration." (pp. 17-18) Foakes chooses to maintain Henton because, "as Pooler noted, the chronicler's words account for the error, "a vaine prophesie which one Nicholas Hopkins, a monke of an house of the Chartreux order beside Bristow, called Henton, sometime his confessor had opened unto him" (Pooler p. 863)." (p. 93) I have chosen Hopkins, in keeping with Theobald, Oxford, and McMullan.
I have chosen to indicate that the Surveyor is quoting the Duke at this point, as he does further down the passage.
